Experiment_description: The experiments involved transforming input sequences into chain-graphs, then training a lightweight GCN with two GCNConv layers, followed by global mean pooling and a linear classifier, to predict hidden labels using the SPR_BENCH dataset.
Significance: These experiments are important as they establish a baseline for using GCNs in sequence classification tasks. The insights gained into model performance, particularly in terms of accuracy and loss metrics, provide a foundation for further development and improvement of the model.
Description: Sequences were converted into chain-graphs with two-character tokens as nodes. These graphs were processed using GCNConv layers, followed by pooling and classification, with training on the SPR_BENCH dataset. Performance was evaluated using dual-weighted accuracy, and metrics were logged for reproducibility.

List_of_included_plots.description: This plot shows the cross-entropy loss for both training and validation datasets over five epochs.
List_of_included_plots.analysis: The plot indicates effective learning and generalization with a consistent decrease in both training and validation loss, and no signs of overfitting.

List_of_included_plots.description: This plot demonstrates the validation dual-weighted accuracy across five epochs.
List_of_included_plots.analysis: The steady increase in accuracy supports the effectiveness of the GCN-based approach for the SPR task, achieving over 91% accuracy.

List_of_included_plots.description: The confusion matrix provides a breakdown of the model's predictions against the ground truth.
List_of_included_plots.analysis: High diagonal values indicate accurate predictions, with minimal misclassifications, suggesting strong model performance.

Key_numerical_results.analysis: Indicates high performance and effective handling of sequence variations in color and shape.
Reflects effective learning with no overfitting observed.
Suggests good generalization to new data.
Slightly lower than other nodes, indicating room for improvement.
Indicates effective model performance with potential to reduce false positives.
